page.title: 09 Hops in Lamberhurst
page.content: The importance of{hops}can be traced to the last century when in 1894 a part of the parish of Lamberhurst in Sussex, voted to join Kent because the price paid for hops was always higher. Hops are perenials, and the dark purple shoots can be seen coming through the earth in March. Then farm_workers start{stringing,} which means they use a long pole to put string from the screw_pegs in the ground to the wire work, which is about 15 feet above. In April and May workers train the hops around the string in a clockwise direction. This is often called {hop_twiddling.}In June,{heading }is carried out. This means twisting any loose hop heads round the strings. At the end of July the hops are in flower which is called a{burr.}After 3 weeks, the burr turns into a soft, cone shaped fruit.
